Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 4 hours
5-15 (more for the midterm and final projects)
Less than 5.
AP- 60 mins most weeks, more when presentations/assignments due
On average, about one hour. Around midterm/final about 3-5 hours.
Approx 3 hours per week for most weeks but more in weeks during which there was a presentation or project due.
5 hours per week
3, before switching enrollment status to Auditor
~10 (midterm and final project much longer)
Faster return on homework
I really liked that the first hour of class was a lecture, and the second half of class was meeting with your group to discuss the weekly homework and make progress on your project.

The course was a great introduction to the field of implementation science. However, I do wish it were a little less clinical/medical based, with a greater focus on implementation science in public health.

It was a good and comprehensive introduction to the field of implementation science.  I liked how the course was structured around a semester-long individual/group project so that each week's lecture could be applied in the homework to a topic that each student was interested in.

I found this course to provide a useful background in implementation research and its key concepts. I appreciated how the assignments were intended to represent a scaffolded approach to developing a proposal to conduct implementation research as well as the liberty to explore the application of implementation science on a topic of my own choice. I also appreciated how the final assignment represented a real-world product that an implementation researcher would be expected to produce. Finally, I liked how the instructor directed us to additional resources to continue training in implementation science.

I think the class could be improved by better scaffolding the assignments to build towards the final project. This could be done by providing clearer instructions and expectations for each of the assignments and by expediting feedback so that it can be incorporated into subsequent assignments. I often felt that feedback provided on assignments seemed to convey contradictory or unreasonable assignment expectations. Additionally, some of the assignments could be improved by better tying them to the final project. I also think it would have been helpful to explore some of the concepts in a more open-ended fashion during class rather than spending as much time on lecture as we did.

This is one of the best and most useful courses I took at YSPH. It has real-world implications, teaches and encourages critical thinking as well as study design. 
Lecture and discussion with the professor and the TA were definitely the strengths of the course.
The one hour discussion part of class (each class has 1 hr teaching, 1 hr discussion) was ok, but I think it needs to be restructured for best use of time in the course. A lot of students in my class worked on solo projects so that time was partly wasted. A lot of the questions that were generated during that discussion were meant to clarify concepts from class and I think a larger group discussion (including the professor/TA - who even when they did the best job they could circulating, still couldn't address all questions) would have been helpful.

Perhaps taking a bit more time in lecture going over examples of how the concepts are applied (and having more reading examples of concept application, rather than theoretical discussion regarding the concepts) and making the discussion session more interactive would improve the course.

One thing I liked about this course was the chance to practice writing a NIH-style grant. This was an interesting final project, and I appreciated the chance to learn this skill!

However, this course was somewhat of a disappointment in terms of the learning outcomes. Coming into the course, I was slightly confused about what implementation science was. After finishing the course, I am still slightly confused about what implementation science is. In my opinion, the lecture style and homework setup of the course was not conducive to effectively learning about implementation science. I appreciated the discussion time of the course after the lecture, but generally my group was confused about what was supposed to be happening during that time, the classroom was very loud (it always seemed to be too many people for the size of the room), and we did not make any good progress during that time. If we were going to have discussion time, I would have preferred to meet with my group outside of class instead of spending an unproductive hour in class. For the homeworks and group project, it would have been more helpful if we completed the homeworks (after the midterm project) together as a group instead of separately. By individually completing the homeworks, my group ended up feeling confused and conflicted each week about what our group was doing for the final project.

Overall, I was excited for this course but felt that the lectures (heavily focused on communicable diseases), class time structure, and homework/project structure was not effective or enjoyable, and I did not walk away with a much deeper understanding about implementation science.

Implementation science is very important and quite different from regular studies that most do in the scientific research field. Thus it was hard to wrap my head around this at first, but the professor and TFs were very helpful. The cons were that during the discussion half of class, rather than staying within the same final project group, mixing people from groups up, or pairing groups would have been much more useful. There's a wealth of backgrounds in the class, including professionals. I've learned more that one day we were told to mix than the numerous days of talking to the same people and just doing the project, and relying on the Cheryl or Luke to come around for questions.

Dr Davis is a great lecturer who clearly dedicates a lot of time in preparing this class. Really liked the structure of the homework. Liked the structure of class with lecture and then chance to work in teams on the project.

Strengths: The course was designed in a way where each week built on top of each other making it easy to follow along. 
Weaknesses: The course seems to be geared towards advanced professional students and PhD students.

AP- Strengths: Has given me a toolbox of skills to apply to real-world situations, where I might want to address an evidence-practice gap. An evidence-based and systematic approach is used throughout the course.


Weaknesses: Sometimes learning about the theoretical models underpinning implementation science can be a little dry, I think the course would be improved by using real life examples where implementation science has been used. We had some sessions where there was time for group discussions, this wasn't particularly fruitful for our group and perhaps this time could be used for more examples of IS in practice.

I thought this was a very stimulating course. The material is very interesting and relevant to all fields essentially. There was an extensive focus on theory which was difficult for me to wrap my brain around. Perhaps some more case examples along the way would be beneficial to help focus down the theory for people who think more practically.

I enjoyed this course.  My understanding of implementation science has greatly improved.  I might recommend that the time allotted for group work be shortened to 30 minutes so that we can spend more time learning the key concepts from the lecture.

Strengths: Practical. I see myself going back to these notes and utilizing these frameworks in my future work. I also appreciated that we had ample time to work on our project within class.
Weaknesses: Homework seemed a little bit nitpicky. Lecture sometimes felt non-engaging.

I really enjoyed the interactive aspect of the course. The professor incorporated his own experiences into lectures and many of the students in the class also had experience in the area of Implementation Science so I found that I learned a lot from them also.

strengths:
-great introduction to implementation science
-having the grant proposal be the final project was a great way to apply the concepts introduced in class and also experience the process in a classroom setting 
-introduced and discussed concepts and strategies that will be very helpful to use in the future

weaknesses/improvements:
-providing more examples of the process implementation science, as well as type of grant proposals for implementation science would be really helpful for future classes
I think it would have been helpful to have worked on the grant piece by piece each week instead of the weekly assignments which we also went over in class anyway

Strengths- provided a structured way to think about solving implementation challenges. Introduced a relatively new field to me.

Weaknesses- implementation science is still emerging and the concepts can come across more like jargon if you don't really invest the time to understand the nuances and differences. 

I think that assigning groups and topics so early was a little tough- perhaps working through examples as a whole class in the beginning and then establishing the groups more towards the middle of the semester might have made the course a bit more cohesive.
I ended up auditing this course because the material was harder to keep up with than expected.

I went into this class excited about implementation science but unfortunately am leaving quite disappointed and disillusioned with the field. I think this class could have been much more effective if it were kept very small (10-15 students or so). I did appreciate how class was divided into ~1 hour of lecture and ~1 hour of group-work, but the lectures themselves were not that helpful and only made me more confused about the terminology. It also gave off the impression of being a high school class, where the weekly HW assignments felt like busy work with nit-picky grading. I also don't believe that a HW response to an exercise to build a research proposal/NIH-grant in progress can be "incorrect" and felt that these weekly assignments were actually painful and time-consuming. Overall, I think treating this class more like a graduate-level course and less like a point heavy high school course would be a positive step forward, as well as clearer lectures and more in-depth examples.

Strengths: great breadth of information, very supportive instructor
Weaknesses: hard to come out of it with tangible knowledge of everything. we covered so much so quickly that it was hard to retain. i also struggled with attaining a more tangible project till basically the very end. the class is more geared towards clinicians and medical students, so as a public health student with no background in implementation science, it was hard for me to conceptualize everything. i was also one of the only groups that presented specifically on a public health intervention, not clinical intervention. i wish the class more geared towards PH students + actually had tangible projects within new haven

The class provided a good introduction to the field of implementation science and gave students a chance to apply concepts on a sample project. However, there were times when the concepts seemed disjointed and difficult to apply. Instead of multiple individual projects, I wonder if we could develop one research question as a class so that we can apply the concepts discussed in class on that one topic and clarify any confusion.
He was an effective lecturer

Professor Davis was very kind, knowledgeable and provided great feedback on the assignments. Would be nice if example in class very a little more diverse and less clinical for the non-medical students in the class.
Luke is a great teacher and gave relevant and constructive feedback for each homework assignment that was tailored to our individual projects.

I thought the instructor did a good job of structuring the course content and of allowing students to autonomously explore the concepts of the course. I also appreciated the instructor's willingness to meet with us to provide individualized support. Finally, I think the instructor did a good job of focusing above all on supporting our understanding of the key concepts of implementation science.

The main way the instructor's teaching could be improved would be related to the structuring of assignments, as mentioned above. I think part of this would entail having better communication and consistent expectations between the instructor and the teaching fellow.

Excellent professor, his ability to discuss and explain different facets of implementation science is instrumental in teaching this course effectively.
He also truly cares about the projects of his students and goes above and beyond to give good, constructive feedback.

Luke was always enthusiastic about the course and more than willing to explain concepts and meet outside of class to provide feedback on our project. One area for improvement could be in the structure of the course, and potentially having a shorter lecture period and then a lab/discussion section later in the week where groups could come meet with Luke to talk about their individual projects. Meeting individually (our group) with Luke was generally the most helpful time during this course, and I think having a time where he could provide his help and suggestions to each group individually could improve the overall learning experience.

However, overall Luke was a wonderful professor and truly cared about us learning the material and considering all potential barriers/facilitators to effectively applying or "implementing" our ideas.
Luke is great. He is attentive, helpful, engaged, and communicates really well.
Super approachable, knowledgeable.
Great Professor and very nice man. The class had a more mature student demographic and liked the fact that we were treated accordingly.

Strengths: Responded back to questions and concerns in a timely manner. 
Weaknesses: Some of the feedback for the homework assignments were sent back very late, which affected the following homework assignment. It would have been nice if the power point presentations were given before class.

AP: Strengths- well organised lecture material, readings relevant to the lecture material, approachable and gives helpful feedback.
Weaknesses- None

Dr Davis is very knowledgeable and an excellent instructor. He was clear, concise, provided lots of feedback, and allowed the very engaged class to discuss and bounce ideas off each other. The class structure was very useful.
Dr. Davis was an excellent instructor.  He was extremely knowledgeable about the subject, answered questions well, and provided great feedback on assignments.

Dr. Davis was a supportive and helpful professor this semester. He always made sure that we felt comfortable with the content and made extra effort to set up meetings with us to discuss about our project. I really appreciate his time and commitment to his students!

Instructor: Super knowledgeable, approachable, and kind. Always willing to help and give constructive feedback.
Weaknesses/room for improvement: Sometimes lecture felt like it was dragging/wasn't always interactive. Also, the homework grading felt nitpicky.
The instructor was very knowledgeable in the subject matter and was always happy to answer questions or discuss things that may be confusing.

The instructor, Dr. Davis, was a great lecturer and he was able to explain abstract concepts related to implementation science. He was available to answer questions and I had no difficulty reaching out to him. His suggestions and comments for homework assignments were helpful for understanding homework concepts and improving the group project.
Luke is an excellent professor who is willing to spend time with students to help build their ideas. I appreciated his patience and kindness
Excellent

Dr Davis did a great job in many ways. His demeanor is great and he teaches like he recognizes that everyone is an adult in the room. I think he probably has a lot more on his plate than he acknowledges in class with many other duties and I think he's still learning implementation science like everyone else to some degree. His homework and paper feedback were of high quality which I really appreciated.

Luke was wonderful and really has a passion for the field of implementation science. I think his lectures could have been a lot clearer and his explanations could have been more straightforward rather than intentionally/non-intentionally ambiguous. I did appreciate his attention to the group-work portion of class.
incredible instructor, very available to meet, very flexible with students, very knowledgeable and passionate

Very patient and encouraging instructor. 
There were times when difficult concepts were still not explained in a clear, concise manner upon asking for clarification.
Definitely worthwhile
Great class to gain a practical skill while at YSPH. The end project is an NIH-style grant proposal on a project you can work on on your own or in a group.
Great course if you are interested in the field of implementation science. However, it does not focus as much on NIH grant writing skills as laid out in the syllabus.

This is a great introductory course for students interested in exploring the basics of implementation science research. I wouldn't recommend it for students who are interested in the more practical applications of implementation science. Also, the focus of the course is almost exclusively on healthcare settings, and so might not be as useful for students looking to apply implementation science to community-based public health interventions.

Should be a required course at YSPH.

We often talk about interventions that work but I think ultimately, without proper implementation strategies, their delivery is subptimal. Studying this delivery and intervention implementation is crucial. Well taught class that will teach you to look differently at what you know regarding research and give you an introduction to a new area of science.

This course has exciting ideas and concepts to learn and the NIH grant project is a useful skill, but overall the course structure was not conducive to effectively learning and applying implementation science. I would not recommend this course, unless you choose to do an individual project, but I would recommend contacting/meeting with Luke if you are interested in implementation science.
Great course - should definitely take it once in your YSPH career
100 percent. Very practical!!

Some of the theoretical stuff was a bit overly fluffy for me but the majority of the course was completely new for me and found a lot of it really helpful and I could really see how a lot of the knowledge I acquired will be useful in the future. Great Professor, one of the best courses I took this fall.

I would recommend it to another student. I got a lot of insight about the field of Implementation Science and was offered many resources to explore more of the field. The concepts were not difficult but the class would have been better for someone who has an idea of a project they want to pursue.
AP- I would recommend this course if you want to learn how to approach an evidence-practice gap in public health or clinical medicine in a systematic way.

It's an excellent course to think through all the facets of bridging the evidence-practice gap with the opportunity to get feedback on real or hypothetical projects. The course is made very stimulating by the other students in the class (many of whom are physicians or other professionals seeking funding or starting new pilots/programs). The discussions and presentations by everyone really helps to improve the quality of the class.

This course gives a great overview of implementation science.  It is a very tedious subject to learn, but it is presented in an engaging way, and the midterm/final projects really help to establish its key components.

This course will teach you the fundamentals of implementation science. You will not have to spend too much outside time on the course and you will learn so much that you can apply to your career. I would definitely recommend it to you.

I would recommend this course if you have an interest in implementation science and especially if you wish to pursue it in the future. It was a very practical course and taught a lot of valuable skills especially for those interested in doing their own research/implementation science projects.

This course was a great way to learn some of the basic concepts, theorems, and strategies related to implementation science. This course also included behavioral science theorems and strategies for changing behavior that used behavioral science theory. The workload for this course is quite a lot compared to some other courses, but the information and concepts that are taught are useful for students that are looking to implement evidence-based interventions within a particular setting. I would recommend this course to students interested in doing this kind of work in the future.
I would recommend this course to another student, especially if they are interested in grant writing. It is a great practice and Luke is extremely helpful
If you're looking for structured ways to solve issues, this is a great methodology to get familiar with. There's still going to be a lot more to learn after the class, but a very solid introduction.
I would recommend this course for any student planning to work in research settings, as our assignments led up to a mock grant proposal to NIH.

Probably not recommend... for reasons explained above. I went into this class excited about implementation science but unfortunately am leaving quite disappointed and disillusioned with the field. I think this class could have been much more effective if it were kept very small (10-15 students or so). I did appreciate how class was divided into ~1 hour of lecture and ~1 hour of group-work, but the lectures themselves were not that helpful and only made me more confused about the terminology. It also gave off the impression of being a high school class, where the weekly HW assignments felt like busy work with nit-picky grading. I also don't believe that a HW response to an exercise to build a research proposal/NIH-grant in progress can be "incorrect" and felt that these weekly assignments were actually painful and time-consuming. Overall, I think treating this class more like a graduate-level course and less like a point heavy high school course would be a positive step forward, as well as clearer lectures and more in-depth examples.
i would recommend this course to students who have a bit of a grasp on implementation science already. experience in this field will definitely help you retain more information
Good introduction to field of implementation science. Would get more out of the class if you have had some experience with implementation science or have a project in mind.
